title: How do news reporters end their news? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on if they are anchors or reporters. An anchor tends to have a sign-off he or she uses at the end of the newscast. For example, José Diaz-Balart, at the end of his Saturday night newscast on NBC, says “I’m José Diaz-Balart, thank you for the privilege of your time, and good night.” Other anchors doing the evening news might say their name and the call letters: “I’m Lester Holt, and for all of us at NBC News, good night.” Obviously, the closing statement from the anchor would vary depending on what time of the day or night the newscast is on; and at local stations, the call letters are often included in the goodbye. Reporters in the field usually do what is called a “toss” or a “throw”— when they are finished with their story, they let the anchor know they are done by saying something like “Reporting live from [name of city,] I’m [insert name]. Back to you [name of anchor.]” So, for example: “Reporting live from Manchester, New Hampshire, I’m John Jones, WXXX-TV. Back to you Allison.” Some stations don’t say “back to you”— they just end with the name of the station: in Boston, on the channel 5 news, the reporter might say, “Reporting live from Brockton, I’m Mary Saladna, WCVB News.” With that phrase, the anchor knows the reporter’s story is concluded.

When I was a broadcast news reporter, how I ended my 1:30 stories depending on whether it was a LIVE shot or general packaged story. I’d start with the most important information off the top of the story, and end with a conclusion telling the audience what was happening next…such as “So and So could face up to XX amount of time in jail if convicted.” This was the inverted pyramid concept of journlistic story telling. If it was a LIVE shot the story creation would be the same, but to close out I’d say…”Reporting live from the County Courthouse, I’m DB, Eyewitness News 8.” If it was the end of a “packaged” story, I’d say “DB, Eyewitness News 8.” TV Stations used us reporters as marketing tools…faces of the TV station so they always wanted us to identify ourselves at the end of every story… The “Eyewitness News” tag was the slogan our news department used at that time. Today the station uses “8 News Now”.
